content.webTitle: The readers’ editor on... portraying disability

fields.headline: The readers’ editor on... portraying disability
fields.bodyText: If you are lucky enough to be in Bristol this Friday, you might want to hear some extraordinary music played by some extraordinary people. The British Paraorchestra is the world’s first large-scale professional ensemble for musicians with disabilities, founded by conductor Charles Hazlewood in 2012, the same year they performed with Coldplay at the London Paralympics closing ceremony. On the same day, the South-West Open Youth Orchestra will also be appearing in Bristol. It works with young disabled musicians who play a range of instruments, including a custom-made digital device called a Clarion that can be controlled simply by the movement of a musician’s eyes. Bradley Warwick, who has cerebral palsy, plays this instrument and says: “Being part of an orchestra is new to me. I love it, and feel a kind of freedom and belonging. Disability should never be a barrier to enjoying music and getting involved.” Just as the Paralympics have done much to change perceptions of disabled people, so ensembles such as the British Paraorchestra and the South-West Open Youth Orchestra are shifting attitudes by creating a platform for gifted disabled musicians to perform and excel. Coincidentally, emails promoting these examples of positive thinking around disability arrived in my inbox last week, alongside others expressing disappointment at a fictional portrayal of disability – the forthcoming film Me Before You – and at the Observer’s coverage of its imminent release. Mawkishly headlined “Not just a tearjerker: why a tale of love and disability will make us think as well as weep”, the preview piece outlined something of the plot of the film, based on the novel of the same name by the British author JoJo Moyes, and interviewed its director, Thea Sharrock. The story revolves around Will Traynor, a quadriplegic former high-flying banker, played by Sam Claflin, and his carer, Lou, played by Emilia Clarke, and attempts to tackle head-on the difficult issue of disability and voluntary euthanasia. Postings on Facebook and emails sent to me were angry at the paper’s claim that Sharrock “… believes the film offers a chance to pause and reflect on the real value of life … focusing on its serious central issue: what might make life worth living if you are confined to a wheelchair?” “It’s not 1970 any more,” wrote one reader. “Should that really even be a question? We [disabled people] are not some alien species.” She joined others who pointed out that our style guide had long ago outlawed the term “confined to a wheelchair”. Another wrote: “What is this question saying? Wheelchair users might as well go and kill themselves? I am a wheelchair user. My wheelchair does not confine me; it gives me independence.” Some readers believed the paper let the director off lightly when she talked of the decision not to cast a disabled actor as Traynor. “Disabled actors will not become mainstream if they are never cast!,” wrote one, adding: “Sharrock was also not challenged when she says very harmful things like ‘My nephew is in a wheelchair and I hope he will be pleased to see this shown in a way that does not make audiences too uncomfortable. If we had shown Will being taken in and out of his chair, or put in a hoist over a bath, the impression we would give is of difficulty. I wanted to make it more normal.’ Most of us want to see our lives on screen. For us they are normal, and more people seeing those aspects helps to normalise them rather than making them some exotic secret.” The reader felt the paper should have gone further into what she called the “real issue”: Sharrock had made a film about disabled people as a non-disabled person, based on a book written by a non-disabled person, not starring any disabled people, for a mainly non-disabled audience. “I don’t think the message that committing suicide so my partner doesn’t have to live with a wheelchair user is particularly romantic. In fact, I’d go so far as to suggest it’s pretty harmful for people like me, especially those newly adjusting to life as a disabled person. You could have covered the multitude of deep problems in this film. I’m not against discussing death and euthanasia, but when it is one of the key plotlines it becomes harmful. I think that would have been far more worthy of investigation.” It’s hard to disagree with the reader’s conclusion that, in future, editors should take a long look at pieces they commission which involve disabled people and ask themselves whether they are unwittingly propping up outdated and harmful stereotypes. observer.readers@observer.co.uk
